newsitem.title: MEXICO: Son of Mexico City mayor-elect resigns post.
newsitem.headline: Son of Mexico City mayor-elect resigns post.

text.p: Facing a firestorm of nepotism charges, the son of Mexico City's mayor-elect has resigned from his father's staff.

The resignation late Wednesday of Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Batel, 30, appeared likely to stem a brewing controversy for Mayor-elect Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, who made history when he was elected July 6 as the first opposition leader of Mexico's capital city in 68 years under the ruling party.
Until now the post had been a presidential appointment.
Charges of nepotism were splashed over the front pages of Mexican newspapers after Cardenas, 63, appointed his son to a key six-person team to ensure a smooth handover of power in December.
The mayor-elect had said members of his transition team very likely would serve in his government.
Cardenas Batel said in his resignation letter, released late Wednesday, that he did not want to become an obstacle to his father's political fortunes.

"My resignation should not be taken as a first stumble but to the contrary it should demonstrate without a doubt that this will be a new city government...with the sensitivity to listen to the people and exercise power with humility, transparency, integrity and principles," the son said.

The older Cardenas, a twice-failed presidential candidate, is founder of the leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD). He defected from the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) in the 1980s.
His son's role became public on Tuesday when the mayor-elect and a team of advisers visited the outgoing leader of Mexico City, Oscar Espinoza Villareal.
At a news conference after the meeting, Cardenas said there was "no doubt at all" the six collaborators would form part of his cabinet.
But after reporters raised questions of nepotism, the left-wing leader was forced to row back -- though he complained of "wrongful and fraudulent interpretations" about his son's unpaid position.
